title: Verifying Vector Space Axioms
description: Verify that $\mathbb{R}^2$ with standard addition and scalar multiplication is a vector space by checking closure under addition.
hints: Show that the sum of any two vectors in ℝ² is also in ℝ².
solution:
Let $u = \begin{bmatrix} u_1 \\ u_2 \end{bmatrix}$ and $v = \begin{bmatrix} v_1 \\ v_2 \end{bmatrix}$ be in $\mathbb{R}^2$.

$u + v = \begin{bmatrix} u_1 + v_1 \\ u_2 + v_2 \end{bmatrix}$ is in $\mathbb{R}^2$ since $u_1 + v_1$ and $u_2 + v_2$ are real numbers.

Therefore $\mathbb{R}^2$ is closed under addition. ✓

title: Subspace Test
description: Determine if $H = \{\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \end{bmatrix} : a + b + c = 0\}$ is a subspace of $\mathbb{R}^3$.
hints: Check three conditions: contains zero, closed under addition, closed under scalar multiplication.
solution:
1. Zero vector: $0 + 0 + 0 = 0$ ✓, so $0 \in H$.

2. Addition: If $u, v \in H$, then $a_1 + b_1 + c_1 = 0$ and $a_2 + b_2 + c_2 = 0$.
$u + v = \begin{bmatrix} a_1+a_2 \\ b_1+b_2 \\ c_1+c_2 \end{bmatrix}$: $(a_1+a_2) + (b_1+b_2) + (c_1+c_2) = 0$ ✓

3. Scalar mult: If $u \in H$ and $c \in \mathbb{R}$: $ca + cb + cc = c(a+b+c) = c(0) = 0$ ✓

Therefore $H$ is a subspace of $\mathbb{R}^3$.

title: Null Space
description: Find a basis for the null space of $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 0 & 3 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix}$
hints: Solve Ax = 0.
Identify free variables.
Express solution in parametric vector form.
solution:
From RREF, Nul$(A) = \{x : x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_4 = 0, \; x_3 + 4x_4 = 0\}$

Free variables: $x_2, x_4$. Basic variables: $x_1 = -2x_2 - 3x_4$, $x_3 = -4x_4$

$x = x_2\begin{bmatrix} -2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + x_4\begin{bmatrix} -3 \\ 0 \\ -4 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$

Basis for Nul$(A)$: $\left\{\begin{bmatrix} -2 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} -3 \\ 0 \\ -4 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\right\}$

title: Column Space
description: Find a basis for Col$(A)$ where $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 3 & 2 \\ 2 & 7 & 5 \\ -1 & -2 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$
hints: Row reduce to find pivot columns.
The pivot columns of the ORIGINAL matrix form a basis for Col(A).
solution:
RREF of $A$: $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -1 \\ 0 & 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$

Pivot columns: 1 and 2.

Basis for Col$(A)$: $\left\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 3 \\ 7 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix}\right\}$ (from original matrix)

title: Linear Combinations
description: Determine if $b = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix}$ is in Span$\{v_1, v_2\}$ where $v_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}$ and $v_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$.
hints: Set up the equation c₁v₁ + c₂v₂ = b.
Solve the system for c₁ and c₂.
solution:
$c_1\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} + c_2\begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ -1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \\ 1 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix}$

System: $c_1 + 2c_2 = 5$, $2c_1 - c_2 = 1$, $-c_1 + c_2 = -2$

From equations 1 and 2: $c_1 = 1, c_2 = 2$

Check eq 3: $-1 + 2 = 1 \neq -2$ ✗

The system is inconsistent, so $b \notin$ Span$\{v_1, v_2\}$.

title: Linear Independence Test
description: Determine if the vectors $\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 5 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}$ are linearly independent.
hints: Form matrix with vectors as columns.
Row reduce to check if Ax = 0 has only trivial solution.
solution:
$A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 1 \\ 2 & 5 & 1 \\ 1 & 4 & -1 \end{bmatrix}$

RREF: $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -7 \\ 0 & 1 & 4 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$

Free variable in column 3, so nontrivial solution exists.

The vectors are linearly DEPENDENT.

title: Finding a Basis
description: Find a basis for the subspace $W = \{\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \\ d \end{bmatrix} : a - b + c = 0, \; b - 2c + d = 0\}$
hints: Express constrained variables in terms of free variables.
Write the general vector in parametric form.
solution:
From constraints: $a = b - c$ and $d = -b + 2c$

Free variables: $b, c$

$\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ c \\ d \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} b-c \\ b \\ c \\ -b+2c \end{bmatrix} = b\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix} + c\begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$

Basis for $W$: $\left\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} -1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\right\}$

title: Dimension of Subspace
hints: Row reduce to find rank.
Use Rank-Nullity Theorem.
solution:
RREF: $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$

Rank(A) = 1 (one pivot)

By Rank-Nullity: rank$(A)$ + nullity$(A) = 4$

dim(Col$(A)$) = rank$(A) = 1$

dim(Nul$(A)$) = nullity$(A) = 4 - 1 = 3$

title: Spanning Set
hints: A set spans ℝⁿ if every vector in ℝⁿ can be written as a linear combination.
Check if the system Ax = b is always consistent.
solution:
For any $b = \begin{bmatrix} b_1 \\ b_2 \end{bmatrix}$, we need to solve:

$c_1\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + c_2\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} + c_3\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} b_1 \\ b_2 \end{bmatrix}$

System: $c_1 + c_3 = b_1$ and $c_2 + c_3 = b_2$

One solution: $c_1 = b_1, c_2 = b_2, c_3 = 0$.

Yes, the set spans $\mathbb{R}^2$. (Note: it is not a basis because it is linearly dependent.)

title: Row Space vs Column Space
description: For $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & 3 \\ 2 & 4 & 6 \\ 1 & 3 & 5 \end{bmatrix}$, find bases for Row$(A)$ and Col$(A)$. Verify they have the same dimension.
hints: Row space basis: nonzero rows of RREF.
Column space basis: pivot columns of original matrix.
solution:
RREF: $\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$

Basis for Row$(A)$: $\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\}$

Pivot columns: 1, 2

Basis for Col$(A)$: $\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 4 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}\}$

Both have dimension 2. ✓

title: Basis Extension
hints: Add standard basis vectors one at a time.
Check linear independence after each addition.
solution:
Add $e_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$: Check if independent.

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 \\ 0 & 0 \\ 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$ has rank 2, so $\{v_1, e_1\}$ is independent.

Add $e_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$:

$\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}$ has rank 3.

Basis: $\left\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\right\}$

title: Intersection of Subspaces
description:
Find a basis for the intersection of subspaces $U$ and $W$ where:

$U = $ Span$\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\}$ and $W = $ Span$\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}\}$
hints: A vector in U ∩ W must be expressible as a linear combination from both spanning sets.
Set up and solve the system.
solution:
Vector in $U \cap W$ satisfies:

$a\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} + b\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = c\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + d\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}$

This gives: $a = c + d$, $b = c$, $a + b = -d$

Solving: $a = b = c = 0, d = 0$ only.

Wait, let me recalculate... Actually $U \cap W = \{0\}$, so dim$(U \cap W) = 0$.

title: Polynomial Vector Space
description: Show that $P_2$ (polynomials of degree $\leq 2$) with standard operations is a vector space. Find its dimension and a basis.
hints: Verify closure, additive identity, etc.
A general polynomial is a₀ + a₁t + a₂t².
solution:
$P_2 = \{a_0 + a_1t + a_2t^2 : a_i \in \mathbb{R}\}$ satisfies all vector space axioms:

- Closure: sum of two degree-2 polynomials has degree ≤ 2 ✓
- Zero: $p(t) = 0$ ✓
- Inverses: $-p(t)$ ✓
- etc.

Standard basis: $\{1, t, t^2\}$

dim$(P_2) = 3$

title: Non-example of Subspace
description: Show that $H = \{\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \end{bmatrix} : ab = 0\}$ is NOT a subspace of $\mathbb{R}^2$.
hints: Find a counterexample to one of the subspace conditions.
Try closure under addition.
solution:
Check closure under addition:

Let $u = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} \in H$ (since $1 \cdot 0 = 0$)

Let $v = \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \in H$ (since $0 \cdot 1 = 0$)

$u + v = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$, but $1 \cdot 1 = 1 \neq 0$, so $u + v \notin H$.

Therefore $H$ is NOT a subspace (fails closure under addition).

title: Sum of Subspaces
description: Let $U = $ Span$\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\}$ and $W = $ Span$\{\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\}$. Find a basis for $U + W$.
hints: U + W consists of all u + w where u ∈ U and w ∈ W.
Combine the basis vectors.
solution:
$U + W = \{a\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} + b\begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} : a, b \in \mathbb{R}\}$

$= \{\begin{bmatrix} a \\ b \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} : a, b \in \mathbb{R}\}$ (the xy-plane)

Basis for $U + W$: $\{\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} 0 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\}$

dim$(U + W) = 2$

title: Coordinate Mapping
description: Let $\mathcal{B} = \{1-t, 1+t, t^2\}$ be a basis for $P_2$. Find the coordinate vector $[p]_\mathcal{B}$ where $p(t) = 3 + 2t + t^2$.
hints: Express p(t) as a linear combination of basis vectors.
Solve for the coefficients.
solution:
$p(t) = c_1(1-t) + c_2(1+t) + c_3t^2$

$= (c_1 + c_2) + (-c_1 + c_2)t + c_3t^2 = 3 + 2t + t^2$

Equating coefficients:
$c_1 + c_2 = 3$
$-c_1 + c_2 = 2$
$c_3 = 1$

From first two: $2c_2 = 5$, so $c_2 = \frac{5}{2}$, $c_1 = \frac{1}{2}$

$[p]_\mathcal{B} = \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 \\ 5/2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$
